byline.contributor: David E. Sanger was a correspondent and bureau chief for The Times in Tokyo from 1988 to 1994.

abstract: Pres Obama, who will become first president to visit Hiroshima, Japan, where America dropped atomic bomb in 1945, will be forced to address conflicting views of event held by Japan and United States; Japan considers bombing act of unnecessary brutality, while many in US view it as lifesaving step necessary to end World War II; White House says Obama will not apologize for bombing, but visit may provide opportune moment to discuss continued danger posed by nuclear weapons today.
lead_paragraph: Most people in Japan believe the city was a victim of unnecessary brutality, but for Americans of the World War II generation, Hiroshima is at the center of a very different narrative.

headline.main: Obama’s Visit Raises Ghosts of Hiroshima
